She and her companions learned that Fundacion Realidad offers group loans to groups with few members at the beginning and that they charge affordable interest rates and have easy payment plans. They decided to participate because they liked the way they would work with the methodology of the fundacion and because the qualifying requirements are few. That’s what they told us. Rocio is the most enthusiastic group member. Her mother-in-law, Clarita, is a senior citizen and she’s very serious, by the way; she sells peanuts and pottery. Celia, who is the most talkative of the group, has a snack stand and Edith also makes obleas. They believe that the help they get will allow them to see their businesses progress. Rocio in interested in staying the longest because she wants to buy another oblea-making machine so that her production will increase. She makes obleas, which are a typical sweet of this region besides the palanquetas (a type of brittle) which are also made in this region. Obleas can be filled with pumpkin seeds in honey or plain. By the way, they are delicious! Rocio shares with us her method of preparing her oblea mixture: First, she pours water into a 19 liter container. She adds two small buckets of flour. The flour and water are mixed for about 10 minutes and the coloring (two tablespoons) is added. Finally, she adds about 2ml. of cooking oil and she leaves it mixing for 20 more minutes. Then, when the temperature (of the oblea maker – similar to a waffle iron) reaches 30 degrees she places a large spoonful of the mixed dough. The mold is closed for 2 or 3 minutes maximum and the cooked oblea sheet is ready. They continue this way until a sufficient number of obleas to fill several bags has been produced. (More or less they make about 10 bags in 5 hours because their machine has 4 molds available.) Her business doesn’t have a name because her locality is well-known for making this particular sweet; she has had this business for 3 years. She learned this skill when she was 16 years old. She worked for some neighbors on her street that had the same kind of business and she was inspired to open her own business. She married LUIS ALBERTO R. R., who used to be a police officer. However, when he saw that his wife couldn’t cope with her work alone, he joined her and together they run the microenterprise that his wife started. Their factory is located in their own home because they haven’t been able to buy or lease a place that they can equip as a factory. However, he took on the task of conditioning a room in his home from which to work. It is very important for her to see her business succeed because it is their source of income and they have been able to do well with their sales. She is very proud that she has been able to do well with it and that it provides for her family’s well-being. She is proud to have been able to purchase her machine, which is her primary work tool, to produce her merchandise. Every week she provides two buyers that take 50 bags each full of obleas of different colors. Her greatest challenge is that most of the inhabitants of her locality are involved in the production of this very same sweet and because electricity costs are very high. To make matters worse, there is only one electric transformer on her street and it often shorts out. Rocio thinks it’s necessary to install another one so that there will be enough electric power for everyone. In addition, prices of her raw materials have risen. She would like to grow more, have a good supply of raw materials. They need their profits not only to reinvest into the business but also to buy the food they eat and their clothing. She would also like to have a larger space so that she can get newer machinery and that the fundacion continue to support her with loans to increase her production. She has two sons: the elder is LUIS ANTONIO R. R. and is in first grade, and the youngest, whom they call Lupillo, is JOSE GUADALUPE R. R. and is in pre-school. He is very little but very restless. Also living with her are her mother-in-law, who is also a group member, her father-in-law, and her sister-in-law, who is studying to be a teacher. Rocio’s hope for the future is to provide her children a quality of life better than the one she had and to provide them with enough education since she was unable to continue with her schooling. She is happy with this financing because they don’t charge high interest rates and she already saw that the fundacion does, in fact, help out with loans. She feels proud, but nervous at the same time, because now everyone will know who Rocio R. N. is and what she does. She is grateful too to Fundacion Realidad for the support it gives by granting the loans. In her own words she says: “THANK YOU FOR THE SUPPORT YOU HAVE GIVEN US. WE WILL FULFILL OUR OBLIGATIONS WITH THE REPAYMENTS. WE WILL NOT LET YOU DOWN.”

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make obleas (round sweets made with two thin, wafer-like sheets with filling between them).

loans.name: Anonymous Group

texts.es:
Este grupo solidario se llama la pochota  porque asi  se llama la población donde habita la mayoría de las personas que conforman este grupo;  Está localidad esta ubicada en el municipio de Tlalixcoyan en el estado de Veracruz.  El grupo está conformado por  6 señoras que se conocen pues viven en comunidades muy cercanas entre si.  Éste es su primer  préstamo con Fundación Realidad.

El representante del grupo se llama Beatriz L. V.. Beatriz es casada, tiene  40 años, estudió hasta el 6° año, y tiene en total 1 hijo varón.  Ella se dedica a la venta de ropa para damas caballeros y niños, y necesita el préstamo para surtir los pedidos de sus clientes.  Sus clientes se expresan muy bien sobre ella y comentan que es una señora muy trabajadora ya que ella recorre varias comunidades cercanas a su casa en donde vende su mercancía.
Beatriz desea este préstamo para aumentar su negocio, y obtener mayores ganancias y así seguir mejorando su calidad de vida.

Anahí V. R.  también está en el grupo la pochota . Ella tiene 28 años, estudió hasta el 3er año de secundaria, y tiene en total 1 hija mujer.  Ella se dedica a la venta de abarrotes y necesita el préstamo para surtir más de mercancía su pequeña tienda la cual tiene en sociedad con su mamá, quien también atiende el negocio.  
Anahi,  desea este préstamo para invertir en  su negocio, y tener un mejor surtido y con el tiempo llegar a ser una de las mejores tiendas en su comunidad y así tener mejores ganancias  con las cuales  ella y su familia  puedan vivir mejor ya que su esposo se dedica a la siembra de temporada por lo cual ve su ganancia hasta la cosecha de la misma.

Los otros 4 integrantes se llaman Nidia E. P., Esperanza Guzmán R., Guadalupe R. Sánchez, Paula U. Domínguez, y quieren préstamos para invertir en sus negocios como son: venta por catalogo ,venta de abarrotes y café Internet.
texts.en:
This solidarity group is called “La Pochota” because that is the name of the town where the majority of the group members reside. This town is located in the municipality of Tlalixcoyan in the state of Veracruz. The group consists of 6 women that know one another and live in nearby communities. This is their first loan with Fundación Realidad.

The representative of the group is Beatriz L. V.. Beatriz is 40 years old and married. She studied up to 6th grade and has one son. She sells men and children’s clothing and she needs the loan to meet her customer requests. Her customers speak highly of her and they mention that she is a very hardworking woman since she travels to several neighboring communities where she sells her merchandise. Beatriz would like this loan to expand her business and obtain higher earnings so that she can continue improving her quality of life.

Anahí V. R. is also in the “La Pochota” group. She is 28 years old and has one daughter. She studied up to her junior year of high school. She sells groceries and needs the loan to stock up her small store, which she runs with her mother, who also attends to the business.

Anahí would like this loan to invest in her business and have a better assortment. With time, she wants it to become one of the best stores in their community, and as a result have better earnings with which she and her family can live better. Her husband works in seasonal agriculture, for which he sees earnings until the harvest of the crops.

The other four members of the group are Nidia E. P., Esperanza Guzmán R., Guadalupe R. Sánchez, and Paula U. Domínguez. They are asking for loans to invest in their businesses which are: catalog sales, grocery sales, and an internet café.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock their stores

loans.name: Las Gaviotas Group

texts.es:
En una pequeña Comunidad llamada El Mezón Municipio de Ayutla de los Libres, dentro de la Costa Chica del Guerrero, vive la señora Luvia G. M. tiene 29 años, es legitima de la comunidad mencionada. 
La señora Luvia se dedica desde hace 5 años a la venta de comidas y cenas en su casa y en pequeña escala, tiene intenciones a través de los créditos de superar sus ventas y esforzarse por quedar bien y seguir trabajando con los créditos, para poder hacer crecer su negocio, ya que tiene 3 hijos de 11, 12 y 14 años de edad, en la vida ha luchado con todas sus fuerzas para poder sacar adelante a sus hijos en su educación ya que es madre soltera, comenta que es muy difícil la situación económica, pero gracias a las empresas de créditos como Fundación Realidad puede trabajar su pequeño negocio y espera que pueda hacerlo crecer.
Por decidieron formar un grupo de crédito donde están incluidas las siguientes personas:

Nombre integrante del grupo   	Actividad económica
Livia G. M.	      	Venta de Comidas
Mayuribel B. M.     	Venta de perfumes y cosméticos
Juan L. Bedoya	      	Venta de pescado
Yanet C. R.	      	Tienda de comestibles para vender
Adela C. Ramírez	      	Venta de verduras para vender
Gonzala Ramírez M.	      	Venta de comidas
Ninfa G. Martínez	      	Venta de productos del campo 
Julio Cesar L. V.	Venta de ropa
Patricia Martínez G.	Venta de dulces
Juana García S.	        Tienda de comestibles
Estela M. P.	        Venta de quesos
texts.en:
Sra. Luvia G. M. lives in a small community called El Mezón in the municipality of Ayutla de los Libres, in the Costa Chica ("small coast") of Guerrero. She is 29 years old, and a legitimate native of the community mentioned. For five years, Sra. Luvia has been selling lunches and dinners in her house on a small scale. Through the loans, she intends to exceed her sales and make an effort to be well and continue working with the loans in order to be able to grow her business. She has 3 children, 11, 12, and 14 years old and in her life she has fought with all of her strength in order to be able to get ahead for her children in their education. Since she is a single mother, she comments that the economic situation is very difficult, but thanks to the loan companies such as Fundación Realidad, she can work her small business and she hopes to be able to make it grow. They decided to form a loan group that includes the following individuals: Group Member's Name Loan Business Livia G. M. 3,000 Food sales Mayuribel B. M. 2,000 Perfumes and cosmetic sales Juan L. Bedoya 3,000 Fish sales Yanet C. R. 3,000 Grocery store Adela C. Ramírez 3,000 Vegetable sales Gonzala Ramírez M. 2,000 Food sales Ninfa G. Martínez 2,000 Farm products sales Julio Cesar L. V. 5,000 Clothing sales Patricia Martínez G. 4,000 Sweets sales Juana García S. 5,000 Grocery store Estela M. P. 2,000 Cheese sales

Translated from Spanish by Amy McGinty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials and equipment to make food to sell

location.town: Comunidad El Mezón, Municipio de Ayutla de los Lib

loans.name: Amistad Eterna Group

texts.es: En el Centro Focal “German Busch”, se encuentra la Asociación Comunal “Amistad Eterna” tiene 10 integrantes, todas tienen diferentes negocios como de producción, comercialización y servicio. Su presidenta es Juana C., Secretaria de Actas es Bernarda Q. y Tesorera es Aurora Alanota, conjuntamente con la base elaboran su reglamento interno con el cual trabajaran el presente ciclo o préstamo, a todas les agrada capacitarse y visitar al consultorio.
texts.en:
You will find the Amistad Eterna Communal Bank in the German Busch community center. It has ten members who all have different businesses like production, commerce, and service. Their president is Juana C., their secretary is Bernanda Q., and their treasurer is Aurora Alanota. Together with the base they make their internal rules. They work with the rules for the present cycle or loan. They like the meetings and visiting the clinic.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies, raw material, and merchandise

loans.name: Anderson

texts.es:
Nuestro socio ANDERSON pertenece al Banco Comunal “NUEVA LUZ DEL MAÑANA” de la Asociación Arariwa de la Provincia del Cusco del Departamento del Cusco. Es conviviente, tiene 38 años y tiene dos hijos. 

El socio tiene una empresa donde alquila maquinaria pesada como cisterna de combustible y también hace el servicio de asesoria técnica en construcción de carreteras. Ya son varios años con el servicio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su labor. Nuestro socio es un padre trabajador y emprendedor que saca adelante a su familia. El socio requiere el préstamo para comprar equipos para el estudio de construcción de carreteras y software de maquinaria.    
  
El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
ANDERSON, 38, is a member of Asociación Arariwa's "NUEVA LUZ DEL MAÑANA” communal bank. He lives with his life partner and has two children. He has a company that leases heavy road building equipment, like fuel tanker trucks. He also provides technical consulting in road building. He has been in this line of work for several years now and has done quite well thanks to the effort he puts into his work. He is a hard-working, enterprising father who gets his family ahead in life. He needs funding to buy road building study kits and appropriate software. He is grateful for the opportunity offered by this means and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy road construction study kits and appropriate software.

loans.name: María Francisca

texts.es:
La actividad a la que se dedica la señora María F. es a la siembra de frijoles rojos en el municipio de Telica en León donde a diario desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana realiza su actividad con mucho entusiasmo porque anhela mejorar las condiciones de vida de ella y su familia.

Es importante destacar que ella tiene un hijo a quien debe de brindarle los estudios para que logre continuar estudiando y por este motivo es que con mucho ahínco se dedica a su actividad agrícola.

El crédito lo solicita para realizar la preparación de la tierra, siembra de los frijoles y siembra de todos los insumos para llegar a tener una cosecha abundante y así mejorar su nivel de vida.
texts.en:
The work to which María F. dedicates herself is growing red beans in the municipality of Telica in León. Starting in the very early hours of the morning, she carries out this labor with great enthusiasm, because her desire is to improve her living conditions and those of her family. It is important to note that she has a son; she pays for his schooling so that he can continue his education, and for this reason she carries out her agricultural work with great dedication. She is requesting the current loan to purchase all of the necessary supplies to prepare the soil, plant the beans, and ensure an abundant harvest, and thus to improve her quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing supplies to plant beans

loans.name: Tlayecac Group

texts.es:
UBICADO APROXIMADAMENTE A 20KM DE LA CIUDAD DE CUAUTLA SE ENCUENTRA EL PUEBLO DE TLAYECAC PERTENECIENTE AL MUNICIPIO DE AYALA MORELOS.
EL PUEBLO CUENTA CON VARIAS NTRADAS PARA LLEGAR A EL PERO LA MAS FACIL Y CERCA ES POR LA CARRETERA MEXICO - OAXACA  SE LLEGA A LA DESVIASION QUE DICE TLAYECAC - AMAYUCA DOBLA A MANO DERECHA Y TODA ESA CARRETERA LLEVA AL PUEBLO DE TLAYECAC.
EN ESTE PUEBLO LA AGRICULTURA ES LA ACTIVIDAD PRNCIPAL EN ESTA COMUNIDAD,BASICAMENTE EN LOS CULTIVOS DE SORGO Y MAIZ EN UNA SUPERFICIE DE 1234 HECTAREAS Y 195 PRODUCTORESY EN LA GANADERIA ES IMPORTANTEEL GANADO BOBINO, PORCINO Y CAPRINO, ENTRE OTRAS ACTIVIDADES IMPORTANTESSE ENCUENTRA EL COMERCIO, YA QUE AQUI SE UBICA LA ZONA INDUSTRIAL QUE PROPORCIONA EMPLEO EN ZONA REGIONAL LA DISTANCIA A LA CABEZERA MUNICIPAL ES DE 13KM.

EN ESTE POBLADO SE ENCUENTRA LA UDE TLAYECAC LA CUAL SU ACTIVIDAD DE LAS INTEGRANTES ES MAS DE COMERCIO ESTA UDE YA LLEVA 9 CICLOS TRABAJANDO CON LA EMPRESA DE FUNDACION REALIDAD POR TIEMPOS YA QUE DURANTE DOS CICLOS HAN DECIDIDO DESCANSAR POR QUE LAS TEMPORADAS Y LAS VENTAS ESTAN BAJAS Y DECIDEN ESPERARSE APENAS ACABARON DE RECIBIR SU 9NO CREDITO YA QUE PARA LA TEMPORADA DE DICIEMBRE SE VAN A SURTIR.
EN ESTA UDE SE ENCUENTRA LA SRA. AMBROSIA M. Z. LA CUAL HA ESTADO EN EL GRUPO DESDE QUE SE INICIO EN EL 2006 Y HASTA LA FECHA SIGUE CON NOSOTROS ELLA ES CASADA TIENE 4 HIJOS 2 ESTUDIAN Y LOS OTROS 2 YA TRABAJAN Y EL CREDITO QUE SOLICITO ESTE CICLO FUE DE $6000 PESOS  Y LO A A INVERTIR EN SU TIENDA DE ABARROTES PARA COMPRAR HUEVO, LECHE, POLLO, PAN, AZUCAR, SAL, REFRESCO, SABRITAS, ETC, SU NEGOCIO SE ENCUENTRA UBICADO EN CALLE 24 DE FEBRERO NO 28 DEL PUEBLO DE TLAYECAC NOS COMENTA QUE ATIENDE A MAS DE 200 PERSONAS AL DIA YA QUE SU NEGOCIO ESTA EN UNA AVENIDA PRINCIPAL Y ESTA CERCA DE EL CECYTE ENTONCES TODOS LOS ESTUDIANTES PASAN A COMPRAR CON ELLA NOS COMENTA QUE SU NEGOCIO A ENFRENTADO ALGUNOS RETOS QUE SIN EMBARGO NO SE HAN DEJADO Y HAN SALIDO ADELANTE YA QUE HACE 2 AÑOS SE PUSO UNA TIENDA ENFRENTE A LA DE ELLLA Y AL INICIO DIO TODOS SUS PRODUCTOS MUY BARATOS ENTONCES TODOS LOS CLIENTES SE FUERON PARA ALLA PERO PASADO UNOS MESES SUBIERON TODOS LOS PRECIOS Y ESA TIENDA QUEBRO Y TODOS SUS CLIENTES REGRESARON CON ELLA.
EL SUEÑO MAS GRANDE QUE ELLA TIENE ES ABRIR OTRA TIENDA POR OTRA CALLE DE TLAYECAC Y HEREDARSELA A SU NIETO QUE ESTA CHIQUITO PERO ES SU RAZON PARA SEGUIR ADELANTE YA QUE SU HIJA ES MADRE SOLTERA Y ELLA LA APOYA EN TODO.
POR ULTIMO AGRADECIO A FUNDACION REALIDAD POR SEGUIR CONFIANDO EN ELLAS YA QUE COMO HAN DESCANSADO Y VUELVEN A REGRESAR TODO ES SIN NINGUN PROBLEMA.
A KIVA POR AYUDAR A LA EMPRESA A QUE PUEDA SEGUIR AYUDANDO A PERSONAS QUE EN VERDAD NECESITAMOS EL CREDITO PARA PODER HACER CRECER NUESTRO NEGOCIO.
texts.en:
The town of Tlayecac, which is part of the municipality of Ayala Morelos, is located approximately 20km from the city of Cuautla. The town has several approaches but the easiest and nearest is via the Mexico-Oaxaca highway. When you reach the turn-off marked “Tlayecac-Amayuca” turn right and follow that road all the way to the town of Tlayecac. Agriculture is the main activity in this town, especially corn and sorghum, which is cultivated by 195 farmers on 1234 hectares. The most common livestock is sheep, pigs and goats. Among other important activities is commerce because the industrial zone that provides employment in the region is located here; the distance to the municipal seat is 135km. This town is home to the Tlayecac communal bank in which most of the members are engaged in commerce. This group is in its ninth loan cycle with FUNDACION REALIDAD although they took a couple of cycles off because sales were low and they preferred to wait so they have just now gotten their 9th loan in order to stock up for the December season. Ambrosia M. Z. has been a group member since its founding in 2006. She is married and has 4 children, two of whom are students and two are employed. She requested 6000 pesos this cycle which will be invested in her grocery store to buy eggs, milk, chicken, bread, sugar, salt, soft-drinks, Sabritas, etc. Her business is located at #28 24 de febrero street in Tlayecac. She tells us that she has over 200 customers per day because her store is on one of the main avenues and near CECYTE (State-run technological high-schools) so many students stop by to buy from her. She relates that her business has faced some challenges but they haven’t caved in and have continued forward despite having a store open across the street from her two years ago. At first, the competition cut all its prices so all her customers went there but, eventually, that store went bankrupt and her customers returned to her. Her greatest wish is to open another store on another one of Tlayecac’s streets that she can leave to her grandson, who is still a little boy, but who is her main purpose in life and her motivation to continue working because her daughter is a single mother and Ambrosia supports her in every way. Finally, she is grateful to Fundacion Realidad for continuing to believe in them and for letting them return, having taken some time off, without any problems. She is also grateful to Kiva for helping the Fundacion so that it can continue to help people who truly need credit in order to see their businesses grow.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy eggs, milk, sugar, soft-drinks, Sabritas (Frito-Lay-type snacks), etc.

loans.name: María Magdalena

texts.es: María
texts.en: María

loans.use: For her son's graduation.

loans.name: Yahira Yaneth

texts.es:
La señora Yahira S. es una persona muy trabajadora y se ha destacado por vender ambulantemente ropa y cosméticos movilizándose en diferentes lugares con el fin de obtener los ingresos para abastecer las necesidades de su  hogar.

La dificultad que hoy en día ella atraviesa es que no tiene la ropa ni los cosméticos para comercializarlos y por eso es que espera muy confiadamente en que la institución le brindará el crédito porque ella sabe que una vez que los tenga en su mano procederá a hacer uso de su potencial creativo con el que logrará vender toda la mercadería y generar los ingresos para su desarrollo económico.
texts.en:
Yahira S. is very hardworking and works as a street vendor selling clothes and cosmetics in different locations for the purpose of earning income to provide for household needs. The difficulty she is going through at present is that she does not have any clothes or cosmetics to market and therefore she really hopes that the organization will offer her the loan because she knows that once she has them in her hands she will make use of her creative potential and will manage to sell all the merchandise and generate income for her economic development.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics and clothes for resale

loans.name: Concepción

texts.es:
Concepción tiene 65 años, vive con su esposa (Antonia), de 67 años; tiene 4 hijos que ya son mayores y no viven con él, cada uno tiene su propia familia. Los días de este hombre trabajador transcurren en la tranquilidad del campo porque se dedica a la agricultura.

Su rutina de trabajo empieza preparando la tierra con fertilizantes y sembrando la semilla. Los productos que cultiva son la papa, alverjas y choclos, él aprendió a cultivar desde pequeño, aunque no tuvo la oportunidad de conocer a sus padres se crió con personas trabajadoras que le enseñaron a luchar y a salir adelante. 
A Concepción le gusta dedicarse a la agricultura porque es el oficio con el cual ha logrado sacar adelante a su familia y es lo que han aprendido a hacer la mayoría de hombres que viven por esta parte del Perú; además lo considera muy rentable porque la calidad de papa, choclo y arveja que siembra le permiten venderlas y obtener buenas ganancias.
A su vez, también cría y vende cuyes de buena raza, él empezó con esta actividad porque una de sus hijas le regalo un par y luego vio una buena oportunidad de hacer negocio y empezó a reproducirlos. 
En el futuro, Concepción tiene pensado sembrar mayor cantidad de papa y llegar a tener una granja de cuyes.

Este es el tercer préstamo que tiene con MFP y está seguro que será responsable, como siempre, con cada pago; además, está muy satisfecho con el trabajo de su banco comunal porque son personas de confianza. Concepción ya tiene pensado invertir el dinero del préstamo en fertilizantes y abono, también comprará algunos cuyes para continuar con su granja.
texts.en:
Concepción, 65, lives with his wife, Antonia, 67. He has 4 adult children that no longer live with him; each has their own family. His work days pass peacefully because he is a farmer. His work routine begins with him preparing the soil with fertilizers and sowing seeds. He farms potatoes, peas and corn. He learned to farm as a little boy. Although he never knew who his parents were, he grew up among working people that showed him how to work to get ahead in life. Concepción loves farming because it is the line of work that allowed him to see his children get ahead in life and it is what most of the men that live in this area of Perú have learned to do. Besides, he considers it profitable because the quality of the potato, corn and peas that he grows allows him to sell them at good prices. In addition, he also raises a good breed of guinea pigs. He began this activity because one of his daughters gave his a pair as a gift and he saw a good opportunity to make extra income breeding them. In the future, Concepción intends to increase his potato crop and to have a guinea pig farm. This is his third loan with MFP and he is sure that he will be responsible, as always, with each payment. Besides, he is very satisfied with his communal bank's work because they are all trustworthy people. Concepción has already decided that the funds will be used to buy both chemical and natural fertilizers; he will also buy a few guinea pigs to continue with his farm.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and guinea pigs.

loans.name: Fabiana

texts.es:
Fabiana tiene 33 años, está casada con Luis, de 40 años, y con él tiene 4 preciosos hijos: Jerson de 16, Keny de 13, Marlon de 10 y Joel de 7 años.

Ella se dedica a la agricultura, siembra papa, alverja y maíz. Fabiana es una mujer emprendedora, pues además cría cuyes y los comercializa al por mayor a diferentes zonas aledañas. 
Desde muy pequeña observó que sus padres sembraban y cosechaban, así aprendió a la técnica, y hace un año una empresa de ayuda social le prestó un par de cuyes para que sacara cría,  así lo hizo y desde entonces empezó a cruzarlos para comercializarlos. Las ganancias son muy buenas en este negocio, que sumadas a la agricultura le permite vivir cómodamente y así sacar adelante a sus hijos. 
Para el futuro, Fabiana quisiera ampliar su granja de cuyes y vender en mayor cantidad e inclusive exportar la carne de estos animalitos. Ella tiene muchos planes y está a punto de conseguirlos, porque la gente que se esfuerza por alcanzar sus sueños, lo logran, pero sabe que el camino no es nada fácil.

Esta es la quinta vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP y está muy entusiasmada en lo que invertirá el crédito, pues adquirirá abono y fertilizantes para sus tierras, además de algunos cuyes más para empezar a ampliar su granja.
texts.en:
Fabiana, 33, is married to Luis, 40. They have 4 beautiful sons: Jerson, 16, Keny, 13, Marlon, 10, and Joel, 7. She is a farmer. Her crops are potato, peas, and corn. Fabiana is an enterprising woman for she also raises guinea pigs that she sells in the various adjacent areas. From a very early age she watched how her parents planted and harvested; that's how she learned the skills. A year ago, a social service agency lent her a breeding pair of guinea pigs so that she could raise the progeny. She did so and ever since has been breeding them for sale. The profits are very good in this business and, added to her income from farming, allows her to live comfortably and to get her children ahead in life. For the future, Fabiana would like to enlarge her guinea pig farm and sell in more comfort or even export the meat from these little animals. She has a lot of plans and is about to fulfill them because people who make the effort to reach their dreams, do so. However, she knows the road in not easy. This is her fifth loan with MFP and she is very excited about how she is going to use the funds: she will buy natural and chemical fertilizers for her farmland and also some guinea pigs to start enlarging her farm.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers.

loans.name: Sofa

texts.es:
Sofa es una mujer con muchas ganas D. salir adelante, tiene 63 años y vive con su esposo Maurelio, D. 52 años, y con sus tres hijos: Isaac D. 28, Andrea D. 25 y Nilda D. 19 años.

Ella es muy trabajadora, se dedica a la agricultura junto a toda su familia; siembran maíz, papa y olluco, los cuales comercializan (al por mayor) en diferentes zonas cercanas a donD. vive. También cría ganado vacuno y porcino con los que recibe ganancias adicionales, lo que le permite vivir tranquilamente, pues así ha logrado sacar adelante a los miembros D. su familia.
El trabajo en el campo no es nada fácil, se debe madrugar a diario y trabajar durante todo el día para tener una buena cosecha, los agricultores son personas fuertes, capaces D. soportar las inclemencias del tiempo para tener qué comer y así asegurar su subsistencia; esto lo sabe muy bien Sofa, ya que aprendió a sembrar y cosechar D. sus padres.
Para el futuro, quisiera sembrar mayor cantidad D. lo que en la actualidad, pues desea que sus hijos estudien en la ciudad y esto es un proyecto muy importante, ya que quiere que sean profesionales.

Esta es la tercera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP y asegura que será muy puntual con sus pagos porque sólo así logrará salir adelante. Con el dinero que solicita comprará abono y fertilizantes para sus tierras, ya que debe asegurarlas con todo lo necesario para que la producción futura sea muy provechosa.
texts.en:
Sofa is a woman with a strong desire to get ahead. She is 63 years old and lives with her husband Maurelio, age 52, and her three children: Isaac, 28; Andrea, 25; and Nilda, 19. She is very hard-working, and she works in agriculture together with her entire family. They grow corn, potatoes and olluco (a root vegetable), which they sell on a wholesale basis in various areas not far from their home. Sofa also raises cattle and pigs, from which she obtains additional profits. This allows her to live in tranquility, since she has been able to proviD. for the members of her family. Working on the farm is not at all easy; one must get up very early each day and work throughout the day in order to achieve a good harvest. Farmers are strong people, able to put up with bad weather in order to have enough to eat and to support themselves. This is something Sofa knows very well, since she learned how to plant and harvest from her parents. For the future, she would like to plant greater quantities of vegetables than she does now, since she would like her children to attend university in the city; this is very important for their plans, since they would like to be professionals. This is Sofa's third loan with MFP, and she assures us that she will be very punctual with her payments, because only by doing this will she be able to get ahead. With the funds she is requesting, she will purchase compost and fertilizer for her fields, since she must supply them with everything necessary to ensure abundant production in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing compost and fertilizer

loans.name: Victor

texts.es:
Víctor tiene 51 años, está casado con Celia, de 48 años, quien tiene una pequeña bodega en su casa; con ella tiene 4 hijos mayores que viven en la ciudad y estudian en busca de un futuro mejor.
Él es agricultor, siembra papa, maíz y alverjas en sus propias tierras; cada día es de sacrificio, porque debe dedicar casi todas las horas del día en cuidar sus cultivos porque aunque no vive con sus hijos les manda dinero a la ciudad y debe trabajar para ayudarlos a salir adelante junto con su esposa. Ellos comercializan los productos que cosechan y obtienen buenas ganancias económicas que como él mismo dice: “me alcanza para poder vivir, porque aquí el que no trabaja no come”, y sabe que se gana más dinero durante la temporada de cosecha.
A Víctor le gusta ser agricultor porque es lo único que aprendió desde muy pequeño y supo poner en práctica lo aprendido para sacar adelante a su familia y lograr progresar. 
Para el futuro, tiene muchos planes, entre los que se encuentran empezar con la crianza de cuyes, ya que sabe que la carne de estos animales se vende a buen precio, además es muy requerida por su exquisitez; también quiere empezar a criar gallinas porque les puede sacar doble provecho por la carne y los huevos que podrá comercializar a diario.

Así es él, un hombre que piensa siempre en mejorar; sobretodo en los negocios, visiona qué provecho le puede sacar a cada cosa y así elabora estrategias para salir adelante en el campo. Con el dinero que solicita comprará algunos cuyes para empezar con la crianza de estos animales y en el futuro llegar a comercializarlos en grandes cantidades.
texts.en:
Victor is 51 years old. He is married to Celia, who is 48. They have a small grocery store in their house. They have 4 grown-up children who live in the city and study so that they can have a better future. Victor is a farmer who grows potatoes, corn and peas on his land. Every day is a sacrifice; he has to spend almost all day on the farm because even though he doesn't live with his children, he and his wife send them money in the city to help them get by. They sell the products that they grow and their earnings are good. Victor says, "I make enough to survive, because here, if you don't work, you don't eat." He knows that more money can be made during harvest time.

Victor likes being a farmer because he learned how to farm at a young age and he knew how to put what he learned into practice to help his family get ahead and progress. He has many plans for the future, including raising guinea pigs because he knows that their meat sells at a good price. In addition, guinea pig meat is highly demanded as a delicacy. He also wants to start raising chickens because he can benefit doubly from selling their meat and their eggs.

Victor is a man who always wants to improve, especially in business. He sees opportunities everywhere and develops strategies to get ahead in the countryside. With the money that he is requesting, he will buy some guinea pigs to start raising. In the future he will raise them in greater quantities.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Chong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying guinea pigs

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria tiene 50 años, vive con su esposo Adolfo, de 42 años; con él tiene 7 hijos, de los cuales sólo 3 viven con ella, porque son menores de edad; Dalma de 17, Jessica de 13 y Jhon de 10 años. El resto de sus hijos ya tienen sus familias propias y cada uno trabaja para salir adelante.

Ella se dedica a la agricultura junto a su esposo, siembran papa, maíz, habas y alverjas. Cada día es una lucha constante para poder salir adelante, aunque ya lo logró con la mitad de sus hijos, aún le faltan los menores. María es una madre abnegada que le gusta que sus hijos estudien para ser hombres de bien, además sabe que la educación es el mejor legado que les pueden dejar. Ella aprendió desde muy pequeña cómo sembrar la tierra y quiere que sus hijos también lo hagan, pero también que estudien para que en el futuro tengan una profesión, lo que se logra con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación. 
Adicionalmente, cría ganado vacuno, ovino y porcino y comercializa tanto la carne como la leche, lo que le permite obtener ganancias económicas paralelas a las que le proporciona la agricultura.
Para el futuro, Maria quisiera sembrar en mayor cantidad y adquirir algunas cabezas más de ganado vacuno para asegurar la educación de sus hijos.

Este es el sétimo préstamo que tiene con MFP y sabe que debe ser puntual con cada pago para seguir progresando y no tener deudas futuras. Ella piensa invertir el dinero que solicita en abono y fertilizantes para cuidar sus tierras y prepararlas bien para futuras siembras.
texts.en:
Maria is 50 years old and lives with her husband Adolfo, who is 42. They have 7 children, of whom 3 still live with them because they are minors: Dalma (age 17), Jessica (age 13), and Jhon (age 10). The remaining children have their own families and each one works in order to get ahead.

Maria and her husband are both farmers and they work together. They grow potatoes, corn, lima beans, and peas. Every day is a constant struggle to get by. Even though they no longer have to support half of their children, the remaining minor children still have needs. Maria is a devoted mother who wants her children to study so that they can become good people. She is aware that education is the best legacy that she can leave them. Maria learned how to toil in the fields at an early age and wanted her children to do likewise. However, an education will give them a chance in the future to have a profession, which requires hard work and dedication.

In addition, Maria raises cattle, sheep, and pigs and sells them for both the meat and the milk. She engages in these activities while farming since they provide additional income. In the future, Maria wants to plant more crops in greater quantity and purchase additional heads of cattle so that she can provide for her children’s education.

This is her seventh loan with MFP. Maria knows that she must make each of her payments on time in order to continue progressing and avoid future debts. She will use the money to buy compost and fertilizer to maintain her land and prepare it for future crops.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase compost & fertilizer

loans.name: Pedro Gilberto

texts.es: Don Pedro de 61 años de edad es viudo, habita en la colonia San Jose, puerto de montaña de la zona norte de Nueva Guinea a 57 Km del Casco Urbano, esta solicitando su primer credito a AFODENIC para invertirlo en su pequeño negocio de pulperia que tiene en su casa de habitacion, el cual comenzo con diñero propio con pequeñas cantidades de productos,tiene un hijo de 25 años el cual le ayuda en el manejo del negocio.  El objetivo de don Pedro es poder aumentar el inventario de su pulperia, con la cual obtiene ingresos que le permiten el sustento tanto suyo como el de su hijo.  El se caracteriza por ser un hombre muy trabajador y responsable en sus compromisos, el mayor sueño de don Pedro es lograr que su negocio vaya creciendo y poder suplir las necesidades de sus clientes, lo cual le permitira mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Don Pedro is a 61 year old widower who lives in the neighborhood of San Jose, which lies along a mountain pass north of New Guinea and 57 km from Casco Urbano.

He is requesting his first loan from AFODENIC so that he can invest in the little grocery store he established inside of his home. Don Pedro started this business with his own money and a small quantity of products. He has a 25 year old son who helps him manage the business. Don Pedro’s goal is to increase his inventory so that he can earn enough money to support himself and his son. He is known for being a hardworking gentleman who is responsible in all of his commitments. His greatest dream is to grow his business so that he can meet the needs of his customers and generate more revenue.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more inventory

loans.name: Jeanette

texts.en:
Jeanette A. is from the city of Gala, Ozamiz City. She is 30 years old, is single, and has one school-aged child. Jeanette owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Jeanette joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Jeanette is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her sixth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa L. is from Ozamiz City. She is 55 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Rosa owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling personal products like body lotion, make-up and lipstick in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2005, Rosa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. Rosa is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 14th from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Rosa Isela

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Isela desde hace 5 años inicio su negocio de Ropa usada de todas tallas y colores. En este momento ella quiere capital para cambiar la ropa de la temporada pasada, ya que en este invierno es muy helado el clima y los clientes le solicitan prendas más gruesas para pasar esta temporada invernal. También quiere prevenirse por la época navideña donde ella obtiene más ganancias y es así como ella compra todo lo de la cena de nochebuena para convivir con sus seres queridos.
Su esposo es una persona trabajadora que la apoya con los gastos del hogar el se dedica a la venta de dulces de leche de todos sabores.
texts.en:
Sra. Rosa started a business five years ago selling used clothing of all sizes and colors. At the moment, she seeks capital to change out the clothing from the previous season. This winter the weather is very cold and customers are requesting thicker clothing so that they can endure this period. She also wants to be prepared for the Christmas season, which is the time she generates the most revenue. This is how she earns the money she needs to buy everything for Christmas Eve dinner and spending time with loved ones.

Her husband is a hardworking person who helps with the household expenses. He sells dulce de leche (a sweet sauce similar to caramel) in all flavors.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for the winter season

loans.name: Migdalia De Los Angeles

texts.es:
La señor Migdalia de los Ángeles M. O., es una señor de 52 años de edad emprendedor dueña de  un negocio de  venta de ropa. El cual comenzó con un capital inicial de C$10,000.00 que lo adquirió producto de un préstamo hace 20 años. Este negocio está ubicado en el Mercado Israel lewite primer anden de la entrada principal del mercado. 

 El crédito solicitado es para invertir en capital de trabajo del negocio; como es la compra de ropa para caballeros, damas y niños, que se vende mucho en esta época del año por las festividades.

Es madre soltera, con 2 hijos a su cargo, uno de ellos en edad escolar. Dice que antes de tener este negocio el trabajaba con su mama en el mercado Israel vendiendo ambulante ropa.

Lleva 21 créditos en  CEPRODEL a lo largo de 5 años los cuales ha invertido en su negocio con los que ha ido creciendo, diversificando su productos, esto gracias a los financiamientos otorgados por CEPRODEL.
texts.en:
Sra. Migdalia de los Ángeles M. O. is 52 years old and an entrepreneur who manages her own clothing business. She started with initial capital of 10,000 NIO from a loan she received 20 years ago and used the funds to acquire merchandise. Her business is located at the Israel Lewite Market and can be found upon walking through the main entrance.

The loan she is requesting will be used as operating capital for her business. She plans to buy clothing for men, women, and children. Her sales go up during this time of the year because of the holidays.

Migdalia is a single mother with two dependent children, of whom one is of school age. She says that before she had this business, she worked with her mother selling clothes as a street vendor through the Israel Market.

Migdalia has had 21 previous loans with CEPRODEL over a five year period. She used the money to invest in her business, which has grown as a result of diversifying her products. She thanks CEPRODEL for providing her with financing.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing to sell

loans.name: Edgar Alberto

texts.es: Edgar Alberto P. E. es padre de 3 hijos a los cuales quiere darles un buen patrimonio y mejor calidad de vida. La casa donde esta familia se fue construyendo con préstamos de aquí,  con este crédito ya será el tercero en el que ha demostrado ser una persona puntual en sus pagos. El agradece el apoyo brindado,  su casa la ha construido con préstamos de esta institución. Ahora el requiere de su apoyo para comprar Vitropiso y alambrado para empezar habitar la recamara. Sus hijos empiezan a crecer y el desea que cada uno tenga su propia recamara para darles privacidad a cada uno de ellos.
texts.en:
Edgar Alberto P. E. is the father of three children for whom he wants to provide a good inheritance and a better quality of life. The house that he constructed for his family was funded with loans from our Institution. He will be receiving his third loan since he has demonstrated that he punctual with his payments. Edgar is grateful to the Institution for helping him build his house. He plans to buy ceramic flooring and electrical wiring for the bedrooms. His children are growing up so he wants everyone to have their own bedroom so that each one can have privacy.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for materials & labor required to finish the bedrooms

loans.name: Sergio

texts.es:
Sergio N. M. y su esposa son una joven pareja que a pesar de la edad  piensan el futuro ya que de ellos dependen tres hijos a los que quieren darles mejor calidad de vida y un buen patrimonio para cuando ellos sean grandes. 
Esta feliz familia como va creciendo cada día, en el que desea empezar una construcción en  planta alta de su hogar; ya que esta es muy pequeña y es de interés social. Para poder realizar su proyecto quieren ir comprando el material y pagar la mano de obra del albañil y así comenzar una nueva habitación para confort de la familia.
texts.en:
Sergio N. M. and his wife are a young couple. Despite their age, they are always thinking about the future because they have three dependent children for whom they want to provide a better quality of life and a nice inheritance for when they become older.

This happy family is growing each day, so they want to add an upper floor to their tiny house. In order to complete this project, they want to buy the materials and pay for the labor of a builder. They hope to have a new living space to provide comfort for their family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for materials & labor to add an upper floor to the house

loans.name: Martha Lorena

texts.es:
La señora Martha Lorena R. F., es un señor de 52 años de edad emprendedora dueña de un negocio de venta de ropa y calzado. El cual comenzó con un capital inicial de C$15,000.00 que lo adquirió producto de un préstamo hace 20 años. Este negocio está ubicado en Mercado Israel lewite entrada principal de la COTRAN 

 El crédito solicitado es para invertir en capital de trabajo del negocio; como es la compra de ropa y Calzado para caballeros, damas y niños, que se vende mucho en esta época del año por las festividades.

Es madre soltera, con un hijos a su cargo, este se encuentra en edad escolar. Dice que antes de tener este negocio ella Trabajaba como domestica.

Lleva 21 créditos en  CEPRODEL a lo largo de 5 años los cuales ha invertido en su negocio con los que ha ido creciendo, diversificando sus productos para poder competir en el mercado, esto gracias a los financiamientos otorgados por CEPRODEL.
texts.en:
Sra. Martha Lorena R. F. is a 52 year old entrepreneur who owns a business selling clothes and shoes. She started with initial capital of 15,000 NIO from a loan she received 20 years ago and used the funds to acquire merchandise. Her business is located in the Israel Lewite Market near the main entrance of COTRAN (the primary bus terminal).

The loan she is requesting will be used as operating capital for her business. She plans to buy clothing and shoes for men, women, and children. Her sales go up during this time of the year because of the holidays.

Martha is a single mother with a dependent child who is of school age. She says that before she had this business, she worked as a housekeeper.

Martha has had 21 previous loans with CEPRODEL over a five year period. She used the money to invest in her business, which has grown as a result of diversifying her products so that she could be competitive in the market. She thanks CEPRODEL for providing her with financing.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing & shoes

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en: Mrs. Ellen A. is from the town of Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old, is married, and is blessed with three adult children. Ellen owns and operates a business selling a variety of foods like tempura (deep-fried, battered seafood or vegetables), kikiam (ground pork and vegetables wrapped in bean curd sheets then deep-fried until golden) and other snacks in the local community. She earns 5,000 per month. In 2004, Ellen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her business. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Teav

texts.en:
Teav M. is a 41-year-old married woman with four children. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband and children.

To make a living, she sells vegetables at a local market. By doing so, she is able to earn an income of approximately $1.50 per day. Her husband, meanwhile, is motorbike repairman, and he earns approximately $5 per day. These sources of incomes help to pay for the family's living expenses. M. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living by generating additional income. Therefore, M. is asking for a loan in the amount of $500 to purchase a machine to start a new business: specifically, she would like to charge batteries for the people in her village. This would be her third loan through CREDIT MFI, Kiva's partner.

loans.use: To embark on a new business venture by purchasing a battery recharging machine

loans.name: Uy

texts.en:
Uy R. is a 41-year-old married woman with six children. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband and children.

To make a living, she sells Cambodian noodles at a local market; by doing so, she is able to earn approximately $3 per day. Her husband, meanwhile, transports dirt (for fill) in their town, and he earns approximately $6 per day. These sources of income from R. and her husband help to cover their family's living expenses. R. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living by generating additional income. R. is now asking for a loan in the amount of $1,200 to purchase a motorbike so that one of her children can commute to work. With the remainder of the loan proceeds, she wants to purchase dirt to fill in the land at her home. This would be her second loan through CREDIT MFI, Kiva's partner.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike (for her child to commute to work) and dirt (to fill in the land at her home)

loans.name: Derlina

texts.en:
Derlina A. is a 38-year-old woman from the town of Maddurulug Enrile, Cagayan. Derlina is married, and she has three school-age children.

To make a living, Derlina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector. Specifically, she raises livestock (primarily sheep) and later sells the animals for a profit. Derlina notes that she just started this business. In 2009, Derlina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services; as a result, she now has the ability to engage in business activities, and she expects to improve her family's standard of living. Derlina is requesting a loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP ($125), which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and to sell in the future. This loan would be the first loan taken out by Derlina via ASKI. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's school tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 21 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas of the country, and its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen/women, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional livestock

Ren P. says that her customers base is growing but her cakes are not enough to fulfill the needs customer demands. Therefore, she needs a loan to purchase more essential ingredients and other materials in order to produce more cakes for her customers and provide more for her family.

loans.name: Nou

texts.en: Nou C., 30, lives with his wife and one young child in Phnom Penh. He buys bread from a bakery, which he then resells. On average, he is able to make about USD $7 of profit every day. His wife, pictured here, has been selling duck eggs on the roadside to earn a living, and is able to make around USD $5 of profit each day. Nou C. is asking for a loan of USD $500 so his wife can reinvest in her business. She will sell more duck eggs as well as roast beef and beer.

loans.use: to help his wife expand her business

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Heng S., 24, is a widow and lives with her two young children. She sells dessert and makes about US$5 of profit every day.

Heng S. is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to reinvest in her dessert business as well as to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to transport her equipment.

loans.use: To invest in her business and to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to transport her equipment

loans.name: Nora

texts.en: This is Nora D. C., a 39 year old entrepreneur from Dasmariñas, Cavite. Her husband, Edgardo, also 39, works overseas. Nora takes care of their only child who is now in grade school. Due to consistent consumer demand, Nora embarked on selling electronic load credits for mobile phones two years ago. She used to sell only a few phone accessories. Now, she is earning P46,000 in net monthly income. Nora is expecting a rise in the demand for new designs of phone casings and other accessories with the advent of the Christmas season. Traditionally, this is also a time when Filipinos call their relatives who are staying or working abroad and so the demand for load credits for mobile phones will also rise. Nora will seize this opportunity so she applied for a new loan in the amount of P50,000 as additional capital. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Ou S., 40, is married with four school-aged children. She is a teacher and a professional tailor and typically makes US$4 of profit every day. Her husband works at the Ministry of Transportation and, on average, he makes US$6 per day.

Ou S. would like to take out a loan of US$600 to purchase a motorbike so that she can use it to transport cloth that she buys from the factory.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport her cloth

loans.name: Mary Ann's Group

texts.en: Mary Ann P. is from the village of Manaoag, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 45 years old and is the group leader of an eight-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Mary Ann is married and has three school-aged children. She owns and operates a business making and selling food, preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 250 PHP daily. In 2007, Mary Ann joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her fifth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Zaida

texts.en:
Zaida V. has three wishes she hopes to fulfill in the next few years: first, that her youngest son finish his studies and get a good job; second, to be able to purchase additional appliances for her home; and third, to expand her business so that she can ultimately improve her family's living conditions. Zaida is 50 years old. Her husband, Ernesto, works as a tricycle driver and also helps manage their duck-raising business. They have four children with one still attending school. The family lives in the village of Mambagaton, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental.

Zaida raises ducks and sells the duck eggs to several regular customers in nearby villages, towns and cities. She thought of this business because their location is very conducive to duck raising with mostly farmlands in the surrounding area.

In 2003, she joined NWTF Project Dungganon to access additional capital for her business. When she received her loan, she used it to buy more ducks and feed. Now her operation is big enough that she has hired a caretaker to watch the ducks (she now has more than 350 ducks and they produce more than 200 eggs per day). She now earns a monthly income of about 24,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) and she saves most of this for the education of her youngest son and also to defray household expenses.

Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP was used as additional capital for her duck-raising business. She was able to repay her loan on time and in full without delays, and she has maintained her good record. Now on her 14th loan cycle, she is borrowing 20,000 PHP which she intends to use as working capital so that she can buy eggs from other duck raisers to meet the demand of her customers.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita M. S., 47, has been in the direct selling business for three years. Aside from direct selling, she also sells mobile phone prepaid credits, generic medicines, and toiletry products as a source of added income. She is the busy mother of three children: one is now enrolled in college while the other two are in high school. She is married to Rolando S., who is a regular employee in a private company. She has made a point (especially now that her children are all grown up) to venture into direct selling of shoes and other apparel to help them with their daily needs.

Teresita has been a member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for more than four years now, and she has received seven consecutive loans because of her good repayment rate. She wants to apply for a 17,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) loan so that she can buy more products to sell to her clients living in Dasmariñas Cavite, a province just south of Manila.

Teresita dreams that someday she will have her own boutique where she can display all her products so that her clients can easily shop. She prays that through her added contribution to their monthly income, she and her husband will save enough money so that they can renovate their house and enable their children to finish their studies and graduate from college.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more shoes

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Mr. Meas P. is 47 years old and has been selling fresh fish in the busy local market for more than nine years. He is married with four kids:one of them is married and lives separately, while the other three are single. His wife stays at home to do the housework and also helps him sell fish. Recently, Meas P.’s motorcycle is often broken. Since he uses it to transport his fish to the market, this affects his profit. Therefore, Meas P. decided to seek a loan to repair his old motor.
Meas P. was not available when the photo taken, so his wife is in the photo instead.

loans.use: To repair his old motor

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes A. is from the village of Baybay, Panalsalan, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 20 years old and is single.

To make a living, Agnes owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fish in the market. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Agnes joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 


About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.
 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Tsetsegmaa

texts.en:
Tsetsegmaa C. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and their teenage son in Zamiin-Uud, a Mongolia-China border town. Zamiin Uud is one of the busiest border towns where many vendors and business owners pass through the border to and from China. Her only son is 16 years old and is a tenth grade student in a local secondary school. Tsetsegmaa is busy keeping up with two small businesses at the same time. She runs a small food store just next to her home. As her food store is located in the busy border area where hundreds of people pass through, her store is usually busy with customers. When she has free time, especially in the evenings, she drives her small car as a taxi in the town. It helps her earn some extra income for the family. Tsetsegmaa says that she would like to expand her business by selling more variety of food products at her store. Besides expanding her store, she hopes to save some money for her son's university tuition. Her son will study in a university in two years time and she hopes to put aside enough money to cover his tuition and his living expenses as a student. She requests a loan to purchase food products for her store. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

Eleanor owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2008, Eleanor joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Eleanor is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her fourth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. loans.name: Jamyanhorol

texts.en:
Jamyanhorol B. is 50 years old and lives with his wife and nine children in Uvs province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. He has a big family and his nine children's ages range from 23 to 1. His four oldest children all work for private companies in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. One child is with his grandparents and herds livestock in the countryside. The other three children go to local secondary school and the youngest son is just 1 year old and stays at home with his mother.

Jamyanhorol bought an old truck two years ago and he has been carrying various freights in the town by request. Besides his truck business, he makes traditional ovens with metal and sells them to locals. He says that he works hard to make sure his big family does well. He would like to see all his children grow up well and be successful with their lives.

He requests a loan to purchase a motor for his truck and metal for his oven-making business.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Lux

texts.en: Lux S., 29, is married with a two-year-old child. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband (pictured) and child. To make a living, she is employed at a private company. She provides the laundry services at that company, earning an income of US $2 per day in revenue. Her husband works at a construction site. He paints the buildings both inside and outside, earning an income of US $5 per day. These sources of income from S. and her husband help to cover the family expenses. S. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $800 to purchase pigs to raise and wood to build a pig cage. This is her second loan from CREDIT MFI, Kiva’s partner.

Un S., age 50, is a widow with five children. She lives in Phnom Penh. To earn a living, she has been selling rice and food and is able to earn USD $5.00 each day. She is aided by her three of the children who are garment factory workers. 

Un S. is asking for a loan of USD $1200 to purchase more tables, chairs and utensils to expand her business.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita T. is from the village of Calaran in Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 63 years old. Anita is married and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Anita sells herbal medicine in the local community. Anita has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Anita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase more VITA PLUS herbal capsules. This loan will be Anita's first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Ben

texts.en: Ben S., 26, is married and lives with her husband and two young children in Phnom Penh. She sells gas, ice and sugar cane juice and also works as a tailor. She is able to make about US$7 profit every day. Her husband provides a service washing motorbikes. On average, he makes US$3 per day. Ben S. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase more cloth so that she can expand her tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase cloth.

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Ros P. is a 33-year-old resident of the rural area of Siem Reap province. She currently owns a bicycle which she uses to pick up fresh fish to sell around her community. She usually earns $2 each day to feed her family. 

She is married with three young, school-aged kids. Her husband is a local carpenter who creates decorative wooden details to go on other furniture, such as tables, chairs, beds, windows, etc. 

Ros P. said that these days she hardly travels anywhere and she needs to pay for a taxi because she doesn’t own a vehicle. Thus, she has requested a loan of US$600 to purchase a used motorbike which will allow her and her family to ride.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorbike

loans.name: Otgonjargal

texts.en:
Otgonjargal G. is 31 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family lives in a house that they built themselves in the suburban area of Ulaanbaatar. Her oldest son is 13 years old and goes to a local high school, while her other two children are 3 and 5 years old and go to a local kindergarten.

Otgonjargal sells small souvenirs at the Narantuul market, the largest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar. She rents a small market stall and sells the souvenirs that she brings from Ereen, China, a trade border town where many cheaper Chinese products are imported to Mongolia. Otgonjargal likes running her own small business and her family has been able to build their home from the profits. She hopes to expand her business by adding more variety of souvenirs at her stall to attract more customers. She would also like to make her house a more comfortable environment for herself and her family. She requests a loan to purchase more variety of souvenirs for her small business. 

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. loans.name: Sainsanaa

texts.en:
Sainsanaa D. is 31 years old and lives with his wife and two small children in Zavhan province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. His son is four years old and his daughter is just one month old. Sainsanaa cuts down trees and sells them as wood during the warmer seasons of spring, summer and fall. In winter, he makes various bakery goods and bread for locals. He is a talented baker and uses his talent for his seasonal business.

During colder seasons, the bakery business is easier and more profitable due to various traditional celebrations where good bakery goods are important. Sainsanaa dreams of building his own home on land that he would own. In order to make his dream come true, he works hard in his various businesses. He requests a loan to purchase necessary ingredients for his winter bakery business. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of the interest paid by borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans.
